title: What are the functions of the cell membrane? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is a very short question which has an indefinitely long answer! I don’t know what level of your biology you’re studying but I’m going to assume you are in the process of, or have previously studied high school biology. The answer is obviously going to be very technical so it’s to your advantage to do your own reading and Google to clarify whatever you don’t understand. Feel free to leave any questions in the comments below too. Also, please don’t copy my answer wholesale for your Biology essay; it’s very uncool and it isn’t going to make you any smarter. Here are some bullet points that give a broad overview of the functions of a cell membrane in a generalized eukaryotic cell: First, you have to understand the structure of the cell membrane. Study the diagram below:  ​ The cell membrane is phospholipid bilayer. Each phospholipid molecule is amphipathic in nature, i.e. it has a hydrophilic (“water-loving”) phosphate head and a hydrophobic (“water-hating”) hydrocarbon tail. The hydrophobic hydrocarbon tails form the core of the membrane which excludes water and prevents it from entering or leaving the cell. The hydrophilic phosphate heads interact with the aqueous medium both inside and outside the cell and stabilize the membrane. Interspersed between the phospholipids are molecules of cholesterol and a variety of proteins whose functions we will get to later. For the cell surface membrane in particular, there are other molecules too, like glycoproteins (protein+carbohydrate) and glycolipids (phospholipid+carbohydrate). Due to this structure of the cell membrane, it serves to: 1.	Separate the cell contents from the external environment. This membrane is specifically referred to as the cell surface membrane. 2.	Allow the formation of organelles within the cell. For example, vesicles and lysosomes are single membrane organelles while mitochondria and chloroplast are double membrane organelles. The advantage of the membrane is that it allows the development of specialized biochemical pathways within the organelle. The higher concentration of enzymes and substrates within the organelle speeds up chemical reactions. Also, the conditions within the organelle, such as pH, can be adjusted to be favourable to certain chemical reactions. For instance, lysosomes have an acidic pH which is required for the optimum function of certain digestive enzymes. 3.	Regulate the movement of substances into and out of the cell. For instance, aquaporins on the cell surface membrane allow water to enter the cell by osmosis. Glucose carrier proteins specifically transport glucose into and out of cells. Ion channels control the movement of ions into and out of the cell. Bulk transport such as exocytosis and endocytosis can obviously only occur in the presence of membranes. Lipid soluble substances, such as steroid hormones and small molecules like oxygen can, however, diffuse freely across the cell membrane. Within the cell, the movement of substances across membranes must also be controlled so that certain processes can occur. For example, the inner mitochondrial membrane contains proton pumps that serve to pump protons from the mitochondrial matrix to the intermembrane space. These protons flow back to the matrix via the membrane protein and enzyme ATP synthase via a process known as chemiosmosis. Chemiosmosis releases energy which is used to phosphorylate ADP to ATP. One specific example of a process in which regulation of substances across the membrane is important is in the generation of action potentials in a nerve cell. The process involves voltage gated Na+ and K+ channels. The phospholipid layers of the myelin sheath that wraps around the axons of neurons serve to prevent leakage of ions and loss of electrical transmission. This works because ions are hydrophilic and cannot pass through the myelin. 4.	Allow cells to communicate with each other. The glycolipids and glycoproteins have carbohydrate chains which allow certain types of cells to recognize each other. 5.	Allow the cell to respond to signals from the external environment. For instance, receptor tyrosine kinases recognize and bind to insulin. G protein coupled receptors recognize adrenaline (epinephrine). 6.	Cholesterol helps to regulate the fluidity of the cell membrane. At low temperatures, it increases the fluidity of the cell surface membrane by disrupting the close packing of phospholipids. At high temperatures, it draws phospholipid molecules closer together and decreases fluidity. The differing cholesterol content of cell membranes can be used to explain why certain types of vegetables grow well in certain temperatures and not in others. 7.	Certain enzymes e.g. adenylyl cyclase which converts ATP to cAMP are found on the cell surface membrane. The electron transport chain proteins used in respiration are embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane which is important because it allows the electron transport proteins to be arranged spatially in order of increasing oxidizing power. 8.	Within the cell, you have the endomembrane system. Lysosomes are involved in processes like intracellular digestion and even autophagy where the cell digests itself. The Golgi Apparatus allows post-translational modifications of proteins to occur. The smooth endoplasmic reticulum allows for detoxification and lipid synthesis. Vesicles allow for the release and acceptance of substances by exocytosis and endocytosis respectively. The rough endoplasmic reticulum is a site of protein synthesis. It shields new polypeptide chains from the environment to allow them to fold into the correct 3D shape. 9.	Some integral proteins are attached to the cytoskeleton of the cell. This provides structural support and maintains the shape of the cell.

The cytoplasm is bounded on the outside by a thin, delicate and flexible membrane known as cell membrane or plasma membrane (also called sarcolemma in case of muscle fibre cell and neurolemma in nerve cell). The main functions of cell membrane are- Cell membrane gives definite shape to the cell and provides mechanical support.Cell membrane is selectively permeable in nature and maintains unequal distribution of Na+, K+, Ca2+ and Cl- ions across the cell membrane, which plays crucial role in generation of potential difference across the plasma membrane. The inside of cell is negative as compared to out side the cell and , potential difference across the plasma membrane is known as resting membrane potential (RMP), when the cell is in resting state. RMP varies from -70 mV to -90 mV.Membrane bound voltage-gated and receptor-operated ionic channels (Na+, K+ & Ca2+- channels), ionic pumps (Na+, K+-ATPase & Ca2+-ATPase) and ion-exchange systems (e.g. Na+-Ca++ antiport) take part in ion-transport across cell membrane, which plays pivotal role in generation of AP & pacemaker potential, muscle contraction, nerve impulse transmission, excitation-secretion coupling, neurotransmitter release, etc.Cell membrane possesses various plasma membrane bound receptors for the physiological actions of various hormones, neurotransmitters and drugs.Plasma membrane bound G-protein takes part in signal transduction. The cell membrane bound enzymes adenylate cyclase and guanylate cyclase catalyze the production of cyclic nucleotides cAMP and cGMP which serve as ‘second messenger’ and take part in signal transduction.Microvilli of intestinal epithelial cells increase the cellular surface area many folds and take part in absorption of digested food like glucose, amino acids, etc.Different muco/glyco-proteins of membranes of RBCs constitute the blood groups.Active transport of proton (H+) by the cell membrane bound H+-pump (K+-H+-ATPase) of gastric patrietal cells is responsible for production of acid (HCl) in stomach.Membrane bound phospholipase C takes part in calcium-phosphatidyl-inositol system.ENDOCYTOSIS (Phagocytosis & Pinocytosis) is an important function of plasma membrane. Phagocytosis (Greek: cell eating) is a mechanism that enables the cells to engulf the solid particles like bacteria. It is shown by cells of immune system- neutrophils, monocytes and macrophages. Pinocytosis (Greek: cell drinking) is, however, intake of droplets of liquid.EXOCYTOSIS: Cell membrane takes part in secretion of secretory materials like digestive enzymes, hormones, plasma proteins, immunoglobulins, etc. and excretion of waste products out side the cell.Ref: Textbook of Biochemistry with Biomedical Significance by Prem Prakash Gupta, CBS Publishers New Delhi, second edition

The cell membrane could be considered the single most important feature of a living cell (with perhaps the exception of DNA/RNA). It's composed of several types of triacyglyerides and other molecules that form a bilayer separating the cell from the extra cellular space around it. The reason a cell can survive is because it can create the perfect environment (pH and ion concentrations) for the cell machinery to operate to reproduce DNA and the cell itself. The membrane allows the cell to manipulate the ions it brings in and releases, both actively and passively. Without the proper intake of ions and other cofactors, the proteins inside the cell couldn't function. Cells often have machinery that allows them to interact with other cells ( some of which are located on the membrane to come into contact with other cells. These come into as cells can inject small DNA molecules (plasmids) into other cells, potentially giving them some form of resistance or a helpful gene. Simply put, everything in life is compartmentalized in some way. The cell membrane is natures way of doing that.

The cell membrane presides cellular homeostasis, due to its selective permeability. For its location, the plasma membrane, in addition to the structural function, performs other essential functions: The function of physical isolation, since it represents a barrier between the intracellular and extracellular fluid liquid.The selective filter function, which lets in some substances rather than others, thus ensuring the biochemical integrity of the cytoplasm.The function of the communication surface, allowing both the information exchange between the intracellular and extracellular environment, is the physical interaction with the surrounding extracellular structures.The function of catalytic surface, since the abundant number of enzymes linked to it, largely involved in the production of intracellular messengers such as phospholipase and sphingomyelinase, which hydrolyze membrane phospholipids, and adenylate cyclase, which synthesizes cyclic AMP .The structural support function, through the membrane anchored proteins to the cytoskeleton and the cell junctions, maintains the shape of the cell.Finally, the cell membrane is involved in complex functions: exocytosis (secretion), endocytosis (ingestion of foreign substances by the formation of vesicles), cell adhesion and amoeboid movement (eg. Leukocytes).

The human body is about 60% water, with out membranes we would just be a puddle on the floor. Cellular membranes are complex mixtures of lipids and proteins designed to keep biochemistry inside and other chemistry outside. They also have a key function in providing energy to a cell via the mitochondria were membranes maintain a separate unit within the cell, and in addition provide a structural matrix for the production of energy. Another key membrane is the membrane surrounding our reproductive DNA, defining an area we call the nucleus. Although the majority of our DNA is confined in this space, mitochondria also have small amount of DNA. Apart from structural functions membrane also play an important part in respiration and in the movement of different nutrients into the cell and waste products out of the cell. The kidneys are an example of the importance of membranes in maintaining the homeostasis of the body as a whole being made up of millions of microfiltration units called nephrons, basically convoluted membranes that filter bad stuff out of the body. Infact we are basically little sacs of chemicals held together in a variety of matrix materials that collectively forms a living organism.

I] Keeping unwanted compounds in the medium out of the cell, II] admitting water, nutrients and needed compounds through the phospholipid cell wall by selective gating, or semiselective passive diffusion, and III] expelling calcium ions and other unwanted compounds through the selective gates on the cell wall. The membrane responds very sensitively to changes in the osmotic pressure of the surrounding liquid medium outside the cell wall : abrupt changes in that osmotic pressure may damage the cell. Semiintermittantly, the cell sends out compounds or “ biotics “ that signal other cells in the community, or transmit genetic material. This discussion refers only to the outer cell membrane. There are other membranes in the cell that cover the nucleus, mitochondria and other structures within the cell.

The primary function of the cell plasma membrane is to protect the cell from its external environment, and to protect the integrity of its interior. Think of cells as individual living organisms (technically, they are: the HeLa cell has been kept alive in vitro since 1951), and the cell membrane as the cell’s “skin.” Many coherently “cooperating” cells make up a meta-organism, (a metazoan animal) where almost every cell hosts a number of sub-organisms (organelles). The cell membrane and some (very few) of its functions is visualized in the animated PowerPoint file Cell Membranes — Living Walls .pps.

The cell membrane (or plasma membrane or plasmalemma) surrounds the cytoplasm of living cells, physically separating the intracellular components from the extracellular environment. The cell membrane also plays a role in anchoring the cytoskeleton to provide shape to the cell, and in attaching to the extracellular matrix and other cells to hold them together to form tissues. Cell membrane of mitochondria and chloroplasts of eukaryotes facilitate the synthesis of ATP through chemiosmosis. Water soluble molecules can’t diffuse into the cell. Cell membrane provides a carrier protein to facilitate its diffusion.

The cell membrane is selectively permeable to ions and organic molecules and controls the movement of substances in and out of cells. The basic function of the cell membrane is to protect the cell from its surroundings. It consists of the lipid bilayer with embedded proteins.There are three different types of proteins found within a cell membrane: structural protein, transport protein and glycoprotein. These support cell structure and shape, move molecules through the membrane and transmit signals between cells.Cell transport includes passive and active transport. Passive transport does not require energy whereas active transport requires energy to proceed. Passive transport proceeds through diffusion, facilitated diffusion and osmosis.

In simple terms the role of the cell membrane is to keep the inside in and the outside out.  The cell runs a lot of chemical reactions to produce life, and these reactions occur under very controlled and defined conditions. So in simple terms you can view the cell membrane as providing  a barrier around an enclosed space, where the cell can maintain and generate the conditions it requires to get the reactions it needs for life to operate under the best possible conditions. Hence my earlier comment about keeping the inside in and the outside out.

Alternate Titles: biological membrane “Membrane, in biology, the thin layer that forms the outer boundary of a living cell or of an internal cell compartment. The outer boundary is the plasma membrane, and the compartments enclosed by internal membranes are called organelles. Biological membranes have three primary functions: (1) they keep toxic substances out of the cell; (2) they contain receptors and channels that allow specific molecules, such as ions, nutrients, wastes, and metabolic products, that mediate cellular and extracellular activities to pass between organelles and between the cell and the outside environment; and (3) they separate vital but incompatible metabolic processes conducted within organelles.” Read More this site will explain all the functions. membrane | biology

Additional functionality will depend on the type of the cell that is part of the organism’s cellular make-up, which means that it is important whether we are discussing plant or animal cells.
